intro: Acronia hispidula, commonly known as the hairy acronia, is a small flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely hairy leaves and small, clustered white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine, stiff hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. Acronia hispidula is often found in wetlands and along the edges of streams, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
